title: Flower Arranging — Introduction
description: The child learns to arrange flowers in a small vase, developing aesthetic sense, fine motor control, and care of the environment. This classic Montessori practical life activity teaches sequencing and encourages attention to beauty.
instructions:
1. Place tray with all materials: small vase, pitcher of water, three fresh flowers, scissors, small towel.
2. Demonstrate pouring water into the vase to halfway.
3. Show how to hold the scissors and trim the stem at an angle: 'We cut at a slant so the flower can drink more water.'
4. Place the first flower in the vase. Adjust the height.
5. Add the second and third, turning the vase to check from all sides.
6. Wipe any water drips with the towel. Choose where to display the arrangement.
materials_needed: 3 fresh flowers (carnations or daisies work well)
Newspaper or mat to protect surface

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all materials on a tray. Place newspaper underneath to catch water drips. Have flowers lying flat on the tray.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to arrange flowers to make our room beautiful!' Show the tray. 'First, we pour water into the vase — about halfway.' Demonstrate pouring slowly.
Pick up a flower. 'Hold it next to the vase to see how tall it should be. We want it a little taller than the vase.' Mark the spot with your finger.
Demonstrate cutting: 'Hold the stem here. Cut at a slant — like this.' Show the angled cut. 'The slanted end helps the flower drink more water.'
Place the flower in the vase. 'Now the second flower — a little shorter so we can see both. And the third!' Turn the vase. 'Does it look nice from every side?'

slides.prompt: Now it is your turn! Trim each flower and arrange them in the vase. Turn the vase to check all sides. When you are happy, choose a special spot to display your arrangement.

slides.text: Wipe any water drips with the towel. Clean the workspace. 'You created something beautiful for our home! We will change the water every day to keep the flowers fresh.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child pour water, trim stems with scissors, and place flowers in a vase with minimal assistance?

parent_notes: Flower arranging is a beloved Montessori practical life exercise that cultivates aesthetic appreciation and care of the environment. Maria Montessori believed that beauty in the environment nurtures the child's spirit. Let the child choose where to display the arrangement — this gives ownership and pride. Inexpensive grocery store flowers work perfectly. If fresh flowers are unavailable, use leafy branches or herbs from the garden. Change the water daily and invite the child to help, extending the lesson into ongoing care.

title: Sandpaper Letters — Group 4 (w, f, v)
description: Introduction to three new sandpaper letters: w, f, and v. The child traces the textured letters while saying the phonetic sounds, building the connection between the symbol and sound for these important consonants.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'w'. Trace with two fingers while saying /w/. Three-period lesson.
2. Present 'f'. Trace while saying /f/ (continuous breath sound). Three-period lesson.
3. Present 'v'. Trace while saying /v/ (voiced version of /f/). Three-period lesson.
4. Contrast f and v: 'Put your hand on your throat — /f/ is quiet, /v/ buzzes!'
5. Review all known letters (now 18).
6. Build new words with moveable alphabet: van, vet, fix, wag, win, web.
materials_needed: Small objects for I Spy (fan, vest, wig, vine, fig, fox)

slides.setup_instructions: Present one letter at a time. Keep review letters in a basket. Have moveable alphabet ready on a mat.

slides.text: Letter 'w': trace the zig-zag shape with two fingers. '/w/ — like the beginning of water and wind.' Three-period lesson.
Letter 'f': trace the curve and crossbar. '/f/ — like the beginning of fish and fan.' Feel the breath on your hand!
Letter 'v': trace the two downward strokes. '/v/ — like the beginning of van and violin.' Put your hand on your throat — feel the buzz!
'Let's compare /f/ and /v/. Your mouth is the same shape! But /v/ makes your throat vibrate. Try it!' This develops phonemic awareness.

slides.prompt: Build these words with the moveable alphabet: van, vet, fix, wag, win, web. Read each word aloud. Can you think of more words with w, f, or v?

slides.text: 'Three more letter sounds! You now know 18 sounds. You are building so many words!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace, produce the sounds of w, f, and v, and distinguish between /f/ and /v/?

parent_notes: The voiced/voiceless pair f and v is a wonderful opportunity to explore how sounds are made. Have the child place a hand on their throat to feel the vibration of /v/ versus the breathiness of /f/. This is phonemic awareness in action — understanding that tiny differences in sound production create entirely different letters. The letter w has a complex shape; some children find it tricky to trace. Let them practice in a sand tray if the sandpaper letter is difficult. With 18 letters, the child can now build hundreds of words!

title: Golden Beads — Introduction to the Decimal System
description: The child is introduced to the golden bead material, learning the names and quantities of units, tens, hundreds, and thousands. This is the foundational lesson for the Montessori decimal system, giving concrete experience with place value.
instructions:
1. Lay a large mat on the floor.
2. Present a single golden bead: 'This is one UNIT.' Let the child hold it.
3. Present a ten bar: 'Ten units make one TEN. Count the beads — 1, 2, 3... 10!'
4. Present a hundred square: 'Ten tens make one HUNDRED. Feel how flat it is. Count the rows!'
5. Present a thousand cube: 'Ten hundreds make one THOUSAND. Feel how heavy it is!'
6. Naming game: 'Show me a ten. Show me a hundred. What is this called?'
materials_needed: Golden bead material (units, ten bars, hundred squares, thousand cube)

slides.setup_instructions: Place the mat on the floor. Have all golden bead categories in a tray. Present one category at a time from left to right.

slides.text: 'Today you are going to meet something very special — golden beads! They will teach you about BIG numbers.' Hold up one bead. 'This is one UNIT. It is small.'
Hold up a ten bar. 'When we put ten units together in a line, we get one TEN.' Let the child count the beads on the bar: '1, 2, 3... 10!' Place it next to the unit.
Hold up a hundred square. 'When we put ten TENS together, we get one HUNDRED!' Count the rows: 'One ten, two tens... ten tens — one hundred!' Place it next to the ten bar.
Hold up the thousand cube. 'When we put ten HUNDREDS together, we get one THOUSAND! Feel how big and heavy it is.' Let the child hold it. Place it on the mat.

slides.prompt: Three-period lesson: 'Show me a unit. Show me a hundred. What is this called?' Mix up the categories. Can you arrange them from smallest to biggest?

slides.text: 'Unit, ten, hundred, thousand — you just learned how our number system works! Everything is built from these four groups.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify, name, and order all four categories of golden beads (unit, ten, hundred, thousand)?

parent_notes: The golden bead material is the heart of Montessori math for ages 4-6. It gives children a concrete, sensorial experience of the decimal system long before they encounter abstract place value. The progression from tiny unit bead to heavy thousand cube is deeply impressive to children. Let them hold, feel, and compare. If you do not have official golden beads, substitute: single beads or buttons for units, popsicle sticks bundled in tens, flat squares of 100 stickers, and a cube-shaped box for thousands. The key is the visual and tactile difference between categories.

title: Africa Puzzle Map — Introduction
description: The child explores the Africa puzzle map, learning the names of major countries and regions. Africa is the second-largest continent and home to incredible geographic diversity, from the Sahara Desert to tropical rainforests.
instructions:
1. Present the Africa puzzle map.
2. Remove each piece one at a time, naming the country. Start with large, recognizable ones: Egypt, South Africa, Democratic Republic of Congo, Nigeria.
3. Point out geographic features: 'The Sahara Desert covers the top third of Africa.'
4. Place pieces back, matching color to outline.
5. Discuss: 'Africa has more countries than any other continent — over 50!'
6. Color a blank outline map of Africa, marking the Sahara and the Nile River.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the puzzle map on a table or mat. Have the globe nearby to locate Africa in context.

slides.text: 'Find Africa on the globe — the GREEN continent! Africa is the second biggest continent in the world.' Show it on the globe, then present the puzzle map.
Remove Egypt: 'This is Egypt, at the very top. The ancient pyramids are here!' Remove South Africa: 'This is at the very bottom — South Africa.'
Point to the Sahara region: 'This whole area is the Sahara Desert — the biggest hot desert on Earth! It is almost as big as all of the United States.'
Replace pieces one by one. 'Africa has more than 50 countries — more than any other continent! Each piece is a country.'

slides.prompt: Color a blank Africa map. Mark the Sahara in yellow, the Nile River in blue, and color Egypt, South Africa, Nigeria, and Congo. Label what you can.

slides.text: 'Africa is a continent of incredible diversity — deserts, rainforests, savannas, and so many countries and cultures!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate Africa on the globe, name at least 3 countries, and identify the Sahara Desert?

parent_notes: The Africa puzzle map introduces the child to the continent with the most countries — a wonderful opportunity for ongoing exploration. At this age, focus on a few landmark countries and major geographic features rather than memorizing all 54 nations. Egypt and the pyramids, the Sahara Desert, the Nile River, and African animals are natural hooks for young learners. Consider pairing this lesson with pictures of African animals or a short video of African landscapes to spark wonder. Montessori geography always moves from concrete (the puzzle pieces) to abstract (understanding the concept of countries and continents).

title: Read-Aloud: Planting a Rainbow by Lois Ehlert
description: Reading Lois Ehlert's vibrant book about planting bulbs and seeds that grow into a rainbow of flowers. This connects to the practical life flower arranging and science themes of plant growth.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What colors do you see? What do you think this book is about?'
2. Read slowly, pausing at each color section.
3. Name the flowers: 'These are tulips. These are daffodils. Do you know any of these flowers?'
4. Discuss the planting process: bulbs in fall, seeds in spring.
5. 'The family planted seeds and grew a whole rainbow! What colors would you plant?'
6. Optional: draw your own rainbow garden.
materials_needed: Planting a Rainbow by Lois Ehlert
Crayons and paper (optional, for drawing a garden)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Planting a Rainbow by Lois Ehlert

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably. Have crayons ready in case the child wants to draw afterward.

slides.text: Show the cover: 'Look at all these colors! This book is called Planting a Rainbow. What do you think they are planting?'
Read slowly through each color section. 'Red flowers: tulips and poppies! Orange flowers: tiger lilies and marigolds!' Let the child name the colors.
Discuss planting: 'Some flowers grow from bulbs — you plant them in the fall. Others grow from seeds in the spring. Both need soil, water, and sunshine.'

slides.prompt: After reading: 'If you could plant a rainbow garden, what colors would you choose? What flowers?' Draw your dream garden with all the colors of the rainbow.

slides.text: 'Gardens are like living rainbows! Maybe we can plant some flowers of our own and watch them grow.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 flowers from the book and explain what plants need to grow?

parent_notes: This book pairs beautifully with the flower arranging practical life lesson this week. Lois Ehlert's bold, graphic collage art is very appealing to young children. The book naturally teaches color identification, plant names, and the gardening cycle. If possible, follow up by actually planting some flower seeds or bulbs. Children who participate in growing flowers develop a deep connection to nature and the patience required by the natural world — a core Montessori value.

title: Sound Cylinders — Introduction
description: The child explores the sound cylinders, matching pairs of cylinders that produce the same sound when shaken. This activity refines auditory discrimination and develops the ability to focus attention through the sense of hearing.
instructions:
1. Present two boxes of sound cylinders (one with red lids, one with blue lids).
2. 'Each cylinder makes a sound when you shake it. Listen carefully!' Shake one red cylinder gently near the ear.
3. Shake a blue cylinder. 'Does it sound the same? No — let's find the match.'
4. Demonstrate shaking and comparing until you find the matching pair.
5. Set matched pairs aside together.
6. The child continues matching all six pairs.
materials_needed: Sound cylinders (2 sets of 6 — red lids and blue lids)

slides.setup_instructions: Place red cylinders in a row on the left, blue on the right. Ensure the room is quiet so the child can listen carefully.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our ears — just our ears — to match sounds!' Pick up one red cylinder and shake it gently near your ear. 'Listen carefully to this sound.'
Pick up a blue cylinder and shake it. 'Does this one sound the same? No? Let's try another blue one.' Continue until you find the match.
'These two sound the same!' Place the matched pair together in the center. 'Now let's find the next match.'
Demonstrate one more pair, then invite the child: 'Your turn! Pick a red cylinder, listen carefully, and find its partner in the blue set.'

slides.prompt: Match all six pairs by sound. Shake gently near your ear — listen closely! When all pairs are matched, can you put them in order from quietest to loudest?

slides.text: 'Your ears can tell the difference between many different sounds! This is a special skill called careful listening.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of the 6 sound cylinder pairs?

parent_notes: The sound cylinders isolate the sense of hearing, training the child to make fine auditory distinctions. This is directly connected to reading readiness — hearing the difference between similar speech sounds. Ensure the environment is quiet during this work. If you do not have official sound cylinders, make your own using identical opaque containers (film canisters, small bottles) filled with different materials: rice, beans, sand, salt, beads, and cotton balls. Make two of each. The child should shake gently and hold the cylinder near the ear, not vigorously. Grading from quietest to loudest is an advanced extension.

title: CVC Word Building — Expanding Vocabulary
description: The child builds and reads a wider variety of CVC words using the moveable alphabet, incorporating the newly learned letters w, f, and v alongside all previously known letters. Focus on reading fluency with three-letter words.
instructions:
1. Lay out the moveable alphabet on a mat.
2. Review: build 3 familiar CVC words (cat, sit, mop). Child reads each.
3. Introduce new words with w, f, v: wet, wag, fan, fig, vet, van.
4. Child builds each word as you say it slowly: '/w/-/e/-/t/ — wet!'
5. Mix old and new: 'Build the word I say.' Dictate 10 words randomly.
6. Extension: child picks an object, builds its CVC name.
materials_needed: Small objects whose names are CVC words (fan, wig, van, hat, cup, pig)

slides.heading: Word Building
slides.subheading: New Words with w, f, and v

slides.setup_instructions: Spread the moveable alphabet on a mat. Place objects nearby. Have a list of CVC words ready.

slides.text: 'Let's build words with our new letter sounds! Remember /w/, /f/, and /v/?' Quick review: child traces in the air or on the table.
'/w/-/e/-/t/ — can you hear the sounds? Find the letters and build the word.' Child selects w, e, t and places them in order. 'Read it! Wet!'
Continue: fan, fig, vet, van, wag. For each word, say it slowly, child builds it, then reads it back.
Now mix in familiar words: 'Build cat. Build fig. Build hat. Build vet.' Speed increases as confidence grows.

slides.prompt: Pick an object from the basket. Can you build its name? Try: fan, wig, van, hat, cup, pig. Build all six and read them!

slides.text: 'You can build and read so many words now! Every new letter gives you more word power.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently build and read at least 6 CVC words including words with w, f, and v?

parent_notes: Word building with the moveable alphabet is the Montessori bridge between knowing letter sounds and reading. The physical act of selecting letters and placing them in order reinforces left-to-right directionality and phonemic segmentation. Always say the word slowly, stretching the sounds, so the child can hear each phoneme. Do not rush to correct — if the child writes 'fan' as 'fn,' gently stretch the middle sound: '/f/-/aaa/-/n/ — do you hear the /a/ in the middle?' The child is both writing and reading simultaneously, which is powerful.

title: Golden Beads — Fetching Quantities
description: The child practices identifying and fetching specific quantities of golden bead material. This builds understanding of the decimal categories through active movement and reinforces the names of units, tens, hundreds, and thousands.
instructions:
1. Place the golden bead bank on a shelf across the room.
2. 'Please bring me 3 tens.' Child walks to the bank, counts 3 ten bars, brings them back.
3. Verify together by counting: '10, 20, 30 — yes, 3 tens!'
4. 'Now please bring me 5 units.' Child fetches 5 loose beads.
5. Increase complexity: 'Bring me 2 hundreds and 4 units.'
6. Always verify by counting together when the child returns.
materials_needed: Golden bead material (full bank: many units, tens, hundreds, and thousand cubes)

items: Full golden bead bank on a shelf
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the golden bead bank on a shelf away from the workspace. The child will walk back and forth fetching quantities — movement is part of the lesson.

slides.text: 'The golden bead bank is over there. I am going to ask you to bring me certain quantities. Ready?' This fetching game uses gross motor movement.
'Please bring me 3 tens.' Child walks to the bank, selects 3 ten bars, places them on the tray, and carries them back.
Count together: 'One ten, two tens, three tens — 10, 20, 30! Perfect!' Celebrate accuracy.
'Now bring me 5 units.' Then: 'Bring me 2 hundreds.' Then challenge: 'Bring me 1 thousand, 2 hundreds, and 3 units!'

slides.prompt: Fetching game: your parent says a quantity, you bring it from the bank. Start simple and get bigger! Can you fetch 4 tens, 6 units, 2 hundreds, and 1 thousand?

slides.text: 'You can find ANY quantity in the golden bead bank! You know units, tens, hundreds, and thousands.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly fetch requested quantities of each category (units, tens, hundreds, thousands)?

parent_notes: The fetching game is a brilliant Montessori strategy that incorporates movement into learning. Walking across the room to get materials gives the child time to think, requires them to hold the request in memory, and provides a physical break from seated work. Place the golden bead bank far enough away that the child must truly walk, not just reach. This lesson should feel like a fun game. Increase complexity gradually: start with single categories ('3 tens'), then combine ('2 hundreds and 5 units'). The child internalizes place value through this repetitive, joyful practice.

title: Life Cycle of a Butterfly
description: The child learns the four stages of a butterfly's life cycle: egg, caterpillar (larva), chrysalis (pupa), and adult butterfly. This lesson uses concrete materials to explore metamorphosis and connects to the natural world.
instructions:
1. Show pictures or figurines of each stage: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, butterfly.
2. 'Every butterfly starts as a tiny egg on a leaf. What hatches from the egg?'
3. 'The caterpillar eats and eats and grows. Then something amazing happens — it makes a chrysalis!'
4. 'Inside the chrysalis, the caterpillar transforms into a butterfly!'
5. Arrange the stages in a circle (cycle): egg → caterpillar → chrysalis → butterfly → egg.
6. Draw and label the four stages.
materials_needed: Butterfly life cycle figurines or pictures
Optional: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle

items: Butterfly life cycle figurines or pictures
Optional: The Very Hungry Caterpillar book
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange the four stages in order on a mat. If using figurines, place them on a tray.

slides.text: 'Have you ever seen a butterfly? Today we are going to learn how a butterfly is born!' Show the tiny egg. 'A mother butterfly lays a tiny egg on a leaf.'
Show the caterpillar. 'From the egg hatches a caterpillar — also called a larva. It eats leaves and grows bigger and bigger!'
Show the chrysalis. 'The caterpillar wraps itself in a chrysalis — like a sleeping bag! Inside, something magical happens. Its whole body changes!'
Show the butterfly. 'Out comes a BUTTERFLY! This change is called metamorphosis — meta-mor-pho-sis. It means a big change.'

slides.prompt: Draw the four stages in a circle: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, butterfly. Label each one. Draw arrows showing the cycle goes round and round!

slides.text: 'A butterfly goes through four amazing stages. Can you name them all? Egg, caterpillar, chrysalis, butterfly!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and sequence all four stages of the butterfly life cycle?

parent_notes: Metamorphosis is one of the most awe-inspiring phenomena in nature, and children are naturally fascinated by it. If possible, order a butterfly kit (painted lady caterpillars) so the child can observe the full life cycle over several weeks. This transforms an abstract lesson into direct experience — the highest form of Montessori learning. The word 'metamorphosis' is long but children love big words! Let them practice saying it. Connect this to The Very Hungry Caterpillar if you have it. The key concept is that a life CYCLE goes in a circle — the butterfly lays eggs that start the process again.

title: Collage — Nature Collection
description: The child creates a collage using collected natural materials such as leaves, petals, small sticks, and seeds. This integrates art with science and encourages observation of natural textures, colors, and shapes.
instructions:
1. Go on a short nature walk to collect materials: leaves, flower petals, small twigs, seed pods, grass.
2. Back inside, lay out the collection on a tray.
3. Provide a sturdy piece of cardboard or thick paper as the base.
4. Demonstrate applying glue and pressing a leaf onto the paper.
5. 'Arrange your natural materials however you like — you are the artist!'
6. Let dry. Discuss the textures and colors used.
materials_needed: Collected natural materials (leaves, petals, twigs, seeds)

slides.setup_instructions: Collect materials from a nature walk beforehand or as part of the lesson. Lay them out sorted by type on a tray.

slides.text: 'Look at all the beautiful things we found outside! We are going to use them to make art.' Show the collection: leaves, petals, twigs, seeds.
Demonstrate: 'I put a little glue on my paper, then press the leaf down. Hold it for a moment.' Let the child feel the different textures.
'Now it is your turn! You can arrange the materials however you like. You are the artist — there is no wrong way to create!'

slides.prompt: Create your nature collage! Arrange leaves, petals, twigs, and seeds on your paper. Glue them down. Make any design you like — a scene, a pattern, or something abstract.

slides.text: 'Look at your nature art! Every piece came from the living world. What textures can you feel? Smooth? Rough? Bumpy?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently apply glue and arrange materials to create a collage?

parent_notes: Nature collage beautifully integrates art and science. The child practices classification (sorting materials), fine motor control (applying glue, placing small items), and aesthetic judgment (arranging the composition). Maria Montessori believed that art should connect children to nature. Avoid giving a template — let the child create freely. Some may make a representational scene (a tree, a garden), while others will create abstract patterns. Both are valid. If you want to preserve the collage, cover it with clear contact paper once dry. This activity can be repeated seasonally to observe how available materials change.

title: Food Preparation — Spreading on Crackers
description: The child practices the skill of spreading soft foods (cream cheese or hummus) onto crackers using a small spreading knife. This develops fine motor control, wrist rotation, and the independence of preparing one's own snack.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Arrange tray: small bowl of cream cheese or hummus, plate of crackers, spreading knife, napkin.
3. Demonstrate: hold cracker in non-dominant hand, scoop a small amount with the knife.
4. Spread with gentle back-and-forth strokes: 'Spread from the middle outward. Not too much pressure or the cracker breaks!'
5. Show the finished cracker. Take a bite!
6. Child spreads the remaining crackers independently.
materials_needed: Cream cheese, hummus, or soft butter

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands first. Arrange everything on a tray. Use a sturdy cracker that will not break easily under pressure.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to make our own snack! We will spread cream cheese on crackers.' Show the materials.
Demonstrate: 'Hold the cracker flat in this hand. Use the knife to scoop a small amount.' Show how much — about a marble-sized portion.
'Now spread gently — back and forth, from the middle out to the edges. Gentle, gentle! If we press too hard, the cracker breaks.'
'Look! A perfectly spread cracker. Let's take a bite. Mmm!' Now invite the child: 'Your turn to make one.'

slides.prompt: Spread cream cheese on 4-5 crackers. Try to cover the whole cracker evenly without breaking it. Enjoy your snack when done!

slides.text: Clean up: wipe the knife, put the bowl and plate on the tray, wipe the table. 'You made your own snack — that is real independence!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child scoop an appropriate amount and spread evenly without breaking crackers?

parent_notes: Spreading is a core Montessori food preparation skill that develops the same wrist rotation used in writing. The key challenge is pressure control — too much and the cracker snaps, too little and the spread does not move. This is excellent proprioceptive feedback. Choose sturdy crackers (water crackers or thick rice cakes work well) to reduce frustration. If a cracker breaks, calmly say, 'That happens sometimes. Let's try again with a little less pressure.' Never rush the child. The reward of eating what they prepare is powerful intrinsic motivation.

title: Phonogram Awareness — Introduction to 'sh'
description: The child is introduced to the concept that two letters can work together to make one sound. The phonogram 'sh' is presented first because it is visually distinct and aurally clear. This builds the foundation for reading beyond CVC words.
instructions:
1. 'You know the sounds /s/ and /h/. But when s and h are next to each other, they make a NEW sound: /sh/!'
2. Present the 'sh' double sandpaper letter (or write 'sh' on card). Trace while saying /sh/.
3. I Spy: find objects with /sh/ — ship, shell, shoe, fish, dish, bush.
4. Build words with moveable alphabet: ship, shop, shin, shed, fish, dish, wish, mash.
5. Read the words back. 'These letters always say /sh/ when they are together.'
materials_needed: Objects with /sh/ sound (shell, ship figurine, shoe)

slides.setup_instructions: Have the 'sh' card ready. Place sh-objects in a basket. Lay out the moveable alphabet on a large mat.

slides.text: 'You know /s/ and you know /h/. But something special happens when they come together. Listen: /sh/!' Put finger to lips. 'Like when we say shhh — be quiet!'
Show the 'sh' card. 'These two letters together always say /sh/. Trace them with me.' The child traces both letters as one sound.
I Spy: 'I spy something that starts with /sh/ — you wear it on your foot!' (shoe). 'I spy something that ends with /sh/ — you find it at the beach!' (shell).
'Let's build /sh/ words!' Build 'ship' together: s-h-i-p. 'The s and h work as a team!' Build shop, shed, fish, dish, wish.

slides.prompt: Build 6 words with 'sh': ship, shop, shin, shed, fish, wish. Read each one. Can you think of any other /sh/ words?

slides.text: 'When s and h come together, they make the special sound /sh/. These letter teams are called phonograms!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the /sh/ sound in words and build at least 4 words containing 'sh'?

parent_notes: This is a landmark lesson — the child's first phonogram! Phonograms (also called digraphs) are letter combinations that make a single sound different from either letter alone. 'Sh' is ideal as the first phonogram because the sound is distinct and familiar (the 'shh' gesture). In Montessori, phonogram letters are typically presented on green cards (vs. pink for single sounds and blue for blends). The key concept to convey: these two letters are a TEAM. They always make this sound together. Point out /sh/ everywhere you encounter it in daily life: 'Look! That sign says SHOP — there is our /sh/!' This builds phonic awareness naturally.

title: Golden Beads — Number Cards
description: The child learns to associate golden bead quantities with their written numeral symbols using number cards. Green cards for units (1-9), blue cards for tens (10-90), red cards for hundreds (100-900), and green cards for thousands (1000-9000).
instructions:
1. Present the number card set: units (green), tens (blue), hundreds (red), thousands (green).
2. Lay out unit cards 1-9. 'These tell us how many units.'
3. Lay out ten cards 10-90. 'Notice each one has a zero — that is the tens place!'
4. Lay out hundred cards 100-900. 'Two zeros — hundreds!'
5. Lay out thousand cards 1000-9000. 'Three zeros — thousands!'
6. Match cards to golden bead quantities: place '300' next to 3 hundred squares.
materials_needed: Golden bead number cards (units 1-9, tens 10-90, hundreds 100-900, thousands 1000-9000)

slides.setup_instructions: Lay the mat out. Have cards in separate piles by category. Keep golden beads accessible.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned about golden bead quantities. Today we are going to learn the NUMBERS that go with them!' Show a unit bead and the card '1'. 'One unit — one!'
Lay out green unit cards: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. 'You already know these! These tell us how many units.'
Lay out blue ten cards: 10, 20, 30... 90. 'Each of these has ONE zero. The zero means there are no extra units — just tens!' Match 30 to 3 ten bars.
Lay out red hundred cards: 100, 200... 900. 'Two zeros! Hundreds are big!' Then green thousand cards. 'THREE zeros — the biggest!'

slides.prompt: Match game: pick a card, then fetch the matching golden bead quantity. Try: 40, 7, 200, 1000. Then reverse — pick beads and find the matching card!

slides.text: 'Now you can connect the golden beads to their numbers! Green for units, blue for tens, red for hundreds.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match number cards to golden bead quantities for all four categories?

parent_notes: The color-coding of number cards is a Montessori hallmark: green for units, blue for tens, red for hundreds (then green again for thousands, beginning the cycle). This color system appears throughout Montessori math materials and helps the child unconsciously absorb place value. The cards are sized so they can be overlaid — 300 (red) + 40 (blue) + 5 (green) stack to show 345. Today we just introduce the individual categories; composing multi-digit numbers comes next. Let the child freely explore the cards and beads. The sensorial connection between quantity and symbol is the essence of this work.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Offering Help
description: The child practices the social skill of offering help to others politely. Through role-playing scenarios, the child learns to notice when someone needs help and offer assistance using kind words and gentle actions.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'Sometimes people around us need help. How can we tell? They might be struggling or look sad.'
2. Role play scenario 1: Parent pretends to carry too many books. 'May I help you carry some?'
3. Role play scenario 2: A younger sibling cannot reach something. 'Can I get that for you?'
4. Role play scenario 3: Someone spills something. 'I will help you clean that up.'
5. Practice the phrases: 'May I help you?' 'Can I help?' 'Let me help!'
6. Discuss: 'We also need to accept when someone says no, thank you.'
materials_needed: Props for role-playing (books, cup of water, blocks)

items: Props: stack of books, cup, blocks
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare simple scenarios to act out. Keep it lighthearted and fun.

slides.text: 'Sometimes people need help. How can we tell? We use our eyes to notice and our words to offer.' Discuss clues: struggling, looking sad, being stuck.
Scenario 1: Parent carries a tall stack of books and pretends to struggle. 'What could you say?' Teach the phrase: 'May I help you carry some?'
Scenario 2: Pretend a friend spills water. 'What can we do?' Model: 'Let me help you clean that up!' Get a towel together.
'Sometimes people say no thank you, I can do it myself. That is okay! We respect their answer. Offering is what matters.'

slides.prompt: Let's switch! Now you pretend to need help and I will offer. Then you create a new scenario. Practice saying: 'May I help you?' and 'Can I help?'

slides.text: 'Helpers make the world a kinder place. This week, look for chances to offer help — at home and out in the world!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify when someone needs help and offer politely using appropriate phrases?

parent_notes: Grace and courtesy lessons are a distinctive feature of Montessori education. Rather than simply telling children to be helpful, Montessori gives them explicit practice with the words and actions. Role-playing makes the abstract concept concrete. After this lesson, look for real opportunities throughout the week: 'I notice your dad is carrying groceries — what could you say?' Praise the child when you observe them spontaneously offering help. Also model offering help yourself, narrating what you are doing: 'I see you are having trouble with your zipper — may I help?' This teaches by example.

title: Read-Aloud: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain by Verna Aardema
description: Reading this rhythmic, cumulative African tale about a herdsman who brings rain to the dry Kapiti Plain in Kenya. This connects to the Africa geography lesson and introduces the child to African storytelling traditions.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This story comes from Africa — Kenya, which is in East Africa.'
2. Find Kenya on the Africa map or globe.
3. Read the story with its rhythmic, cumulative pattern (similar to 'This is the House that Jack Built').
4. Encourage the child to join in on repeated phrases.
5. Discuss: 'Why did the plain need rain? What happened when the rain came?'
6. Talk about how different places have different amounts of rain.
materials_needed: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain by Verna Aardema

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain

items: Bringing the Rain to Kapiti Plain
slides.setup_instructions: Have the globe or map nearby to point out Kenya before reading.

slides.text: 'This story comes all the way from AFRICA — from a country called Kenya. Let's find it on our map!' Point to Kenya on the Africa puzzle map or globe.
Read with rhythm and energy. The cumulative pattern builds — encourage the child to say the repeated lines with you.
Pause: 'The grass was dry and the cows were thin. Why? Because there was no RAIN. What do you think will happen?'

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Can you retell the story? First the plain was dry, then...' Talk about what plants and animals need rain for. Why is water so important?

slides.text: 'This story came from Kenya in Africa. People everywhere tell stories about nature and weather — because nature matters to all of us!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic story and explain why rain was important for the plain?

parent_notes: This Nandi tale from Kenya has a cumulative structure similar to Western nursery rhymes, showing the child that storytelling patterns exist across cultures. The rhythmic, repetitive text is excellent for developing phonological awareness and prediction skills. By connecting this book to the Africa puzzle map lesson, you create a cross-curricular experience that deepens understanding. Children often want to hear cumulative tales multiple times, which is beneficial for language development. The theme of rain and drought connects to science concepts about what living things need.

title: Fabric Box — Tactile Exploration
description: The child matches pairs of fabric squares by touch alone, using a blindfold. This sensorial exercise isolates the sense of touch and develops tactile discrimination, vocabulary for textures, and concentration.
instructions:
1. Present the fabric box containing matched pairs: silk, cotton, wool, linen, velvet, corduroy.
2. First, feel each pair with eyes open. Name the textures: 'This is silk — smooth and slippery. This is wool — soft and slightly rough.'
3. Blindfold the child (or have them close eyes).
4. Place one fabric from each pair on the left, the matching ones on the right.
5. Child picks up a fabric from the left, feels it carefully, then searches the right pile for its match.
6. Remove blindfold to check matches.
materials_needed: Fabric box with 6 pairs of fabric squares (silk, cotton, wool, linen, velvet, corduroy)

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all 12 fabric squares. Separate into two groups — one of each pair on the left, partners on the right.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use ONLY our sense of touch — our fingers will be our eyes!' Show the fabrics with eyes open first.
Feel each one together: 'This is silk — so smooth it slips through your fingers. This is wool — feel the tiny bumps. This is velvet — like petting a cat!'
Put on the blindfold. 'Pick up one fabric from this side. Feel it very carefully. Now find its twin on the other side — using only your fingers!'
After matching all pairs, remove the blindfold. 'Let's see how you did! Did you match them correctly?' Celebrate successes.

slides.prompt: Match all 6 pairs by touch alone! Take your time — feel each fabric carefully between your fingers. Which was easiest to match? Which was hardest?

slides.text: 'Your fingers can tell the difference between many textures! Silk is smooth, wool is fuzzy, corduroy has ridges. You have very sensitive hands!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of 6 fabric pairs by touch alone?

parent_notes: The fabric matching exercise is a classic Montessori sensorial activity that isolates the tactile sense. Using a blindfold heightens concentration and forces the child to rely entirely on touch. If the child is uncomfortable with a blindfold, they can simply close their eyes. Make your own fabric box: cut identical 4-inch squares from fabric scraps. Choose textures with clear differences at first (silk vs. burlap) and add more similar ones as the child develops skill. This work develops the vocabulary of texture: smooth, rough, soft, bumpy, ridged, silky, fuzzy — all words the child can use in writing and observation.

title: Sandpaper Letters — Group 4 Continued (x, y, k)
description: Introduction to three more sandpaper letters: x, y, and k. These are less common letters, but the child now has the experience and confidence to learn multiple letters efficiently. This completes most of the single letter sounds.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'x'. Trace while saying /ks/. 'X usually comes at the END of words — fox, box, six.'
2. Present 'y'. Trace while saying /y/ (as in 'yes'). Three-period lesson.
3. Present 'k'. Trace while saying /k/. 'K makes the same sound as c! We will learn when to use each one later.'
4. Review all known letters (now 21 of 26).
5. Build words: fox, box, six, yak, yam, yes, kit, kid, keg.
6. Celebrate: 'You know almost all the letter sounds!'

slides.setup_instructions: Present new letters one at a time. Have the sand tray available for extra practice.

slides.text: Letter 'x': trace the cross shape. '/ks/ — like the end of fox and box.' Note: x usually appears at the end of words!
Letter 'y': trace the two diagonal strokes meeting and the tail going down. '/y/ — like the beginning of yes and yellow.' Three-period lesson.
Letter 'k': trace the tall stroke and the two angled lines. '/k/ — like the beginning of kite and king.' Note: 'K and c make the same sound!'
'You now know 21 letter sounds — that is almost the whole alphabet! Let's build some new words.' Build fox, yak, kit.

slides.prompt: Build these words: fox, box, six, yam, yes, kit, kid. Read each one! Then write your favorite in the sand tray.

slides.text: 'Twenty-one sounds! You are SO close to knowing every letter in the alphabet. Just a few more to go!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace and produce the sounds for x, y, and k, and build words containing them?

parent_notes: These three letters present interesting teaching opportunities. The letter x is unusual because it typically makes the /ks/ sound and almost always appears at the end of words in early reading (fox, box, mix, six). The letter y can function as both a consonant (yes, you) and a vowel (my, funny) — for now, teach only the consonant sound. The letter k duplicates the /k/ sound of c, which can be confusing. Simply acknowledge this: 'Both c and k can say /k/. You will learn the rules for when to use each one as you read more.' This honest approach prevents frustration later.

title: Golden Beads — Composing Numbers
description: The child composes multi-digit numbers by combining golden bead quantities and overlaying number cards. For example, building 2,345 using 2 thousand cubes, 3 hundred squares, 4 ten bars, and 5 unit beads, then overlaying the cards 2000 + 300 + 40 + 5.
instructions:
1. 'Let's build a big number! We need 2 thousands, 3 hundreds, 4 tens, and 5 units.'
2. Child fetches each category from the golden bead bank.
3. Verify: count 2 thousand cubes, 3 hundred squares, 4 ten bars, 5 unit beads.
4. Now find the matching number cards: 2000, 300, 40, 5.
5. Overlay the cards: stack 2000 + 300 + 40 + 5. 'Read the number: two thousand, three hundred forty-five!'
6. Repeat with 2-3 more numbers.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the golden bead bank on a shelf. Lay number cards sorted by category on the mat.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to build BIG numbers — numbers with thousands, hundreds, tens, AND units!' Eyes light up!
'Please bring me 2 thousands.' Child fetches 2 cubes. 'Now 3 hundreds.' Child fetches 3 squares. 'Now 4 tens and 5 units.'
Lay everything on the mat. 'Let's find the number cards. 2 thousands — that is 2000.' Find the red 2000 card. '3 hundreds — 300. 4 tens — 40. 5 units — 5.'
Stack the cards: place 2000 down, overlay 300 (covering the zeros), overlay 40, overlay 5. 'Read the number: 2,345! Two thousand, three hundred forty-five!'

slides.prompt: Build these numbers with beads and cards: 1,234 then 3,521 then 4,106 (tricky — no tens!). For each one, fetch the beads, find the cards, and read the number aloud.

slides.text: 'You can build numbers in the THOUSANDS! The beads show the quantity, the cards show the symbol. Together they make the whole number.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compose at least 2 multi-digit numbers using golden beads and overlaid number cards?

parent_notes: This is one of the most powerful lessons in Montessori math. The overlay of number cards physically demonstrates place value: 2000 + 300 + 40 + 5 = 2345. The child sees that 2345 is not just a string of digits but a composition of different-sized quantities. The number card overlay is ingenious — each card has the right number of zeros, and stacking them creates the composite number. Watch for the concept of zero as a placeholder: in 4,106, there are no tens (the tens place is 0). This is a subtle but crucial concept that the golden beads make visible — there are simply no ten bars on the mat.

title: Animal Classification — Vertebrates and Invertebrates
description: The child learns the fundamental division of the animal kingdom: animals with backbones (vertebrates) and animals without (invertebrates). Using figurines and pictures, the child sorts animals into these two groups.
instructions:
1. 'All animals can be divided into two big groups. Feel your backbone — those bumps down your back. You have a BACKBONE!'
2. 'Animals with backbones are called VERTEBRATES. Animals without are INVERTEBRATES.'
3. Show animal figurines/pictures: dog, fish, frog, bird, snake — all vertebrates. 'They all have backbones!'
4. Show: worm, butterfly, spider, snail, jellyfish — invertebrates. 'No backbones!'
5. Sorting activity: two labeled mats, child sorts 10-12 animals.
6. 'Which group has more animals in the world?' (Invertebrates — many more!)
materials_needed: Animal figurines or picture cards (6 vertebrates, 6 invertebrates)

slides.setup_instructions: Label two mats. Mix all animal figures/cards in a basket. Have a skeleton picture ready.

slides.text: 'Feel down the middle of your back. Those bumps? That is your BACKBONE — also called a spine!' Let the child feel their own and your back.
'Animals with backbones are called VERTEBRATES. Dogs have backbones. Fish have backbones. Birds have backbones.' Show the figurines.
'But some animals have NO backbone at all! A worm is soft and bendy — no bones! A butterfly, a spider, a jellyfish — no backbones!' These are INVERTEBRATES.
'Here is a fun fact: most animals on Earth are invertebrates! There are way more insects and worms than mammals and birds.'

slides.prompt: Sort all the animals into two groups: vertebrates (with backbones) on this mat, invertebrates (without backbones) on that mat. Think: does this animal have bones inside?

slides.text: 'You can now divide all animals into two big groups! Vertebrates have backbones, invertebrates do not.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define vertebrate/invertebrate and correctly sort at least 8 of 12 animals?

parent_notes: This classification lesson taps into the Montessori approach to zoology, which begins with the big picture (vertebrate/invertebrate) before narrowing to classes (mammals, birds, reptiles, etc.). Children love the concrete connection — feeling their own backbone makes the concept real. Most children are surprised to learn that invertebrates vastly outnumber vertebrates. Insects alone make up more than 80% of all known animal species! If the child asks about challenging cases (like an octopus or a turtle), welcome the curiosity: 'Great question! A turtle has a backbone inside its shell — it is a vertebrate!' These edge cases deepen understanding.

title: Music — Rhythm Patterns with Instruments
description: The child learns to follow and create rhythm patterns using simple percussion instruments. This develops auditory discrimination, pattern recognition, and an introduction to musical notation concepts.
instructions:
1. Present instruments: claves, tambourine, shaker (or substitute household items).
2. Clap a simple pattern: clap-clap-pause-clap. 'Can you copy my pattern?'
3. Transfer the pattern to an instrument: tap-tap-pause-tap on the claves.
4. Create longer patterns: long-short-short, long-short-short (like a waltz).
5. Take turns: 'You make a pattern, I will copy it!'
6. Introduce the idea of steady beat vs. rhythm pattern.
materials_needed: Optional: rhythm cards with pattern notation

slides.setup_instructions: Lay instruments on a mat. Sit facing the child. If you do not have instruments, use wooden spoons, pots, and containers with rice.

slides.text: 'Music is made of patterns! Listen to my pattern and copy it.' Clap: slow-slow-fast-fast-slow. 'Your turn!'
'Now let's use instruments!' Pick up claves. Tap the same pattern. 'Can you play it on the tambourine?'
New pattern: tap-tap-tap-pause (like a heartbeat). 'This is a steady beat. Everything in music has a steady beat underneath.'
'Now YOU make a pattern and I will copy it!' Let the child lead. Repeat their pattern exactly, showing respect for their creation.

slides.prompt: Create 3 different rhythm patterns using your instruments. Play each one twice so we can remember it. Try using different instruments for different patterns!

slides.text: 'You are a rhythm musician! Music is really about patterns — just like math. Listen for rhythm patterns in the music you hear today.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child echo a 4-beat rhythm pattern and create their own simple pattern?

parent_notes: Rhythm is the most fundamental element of music and deeply connected to mathematical thinking — both involve pattern recognition. Montessori music education begins with concrete sound-making before abstract notation. Let the child lead as often as possible; creating patterns is more cognitively demanding than copying them. Household substitutes work perfectly: wooden spoons on pots, rice in a sealed container, hands clapping on the table. The concept of 'steady beat' (the underlying pulse) versus 'rhythm' (the pattern of long and short sounds) is foundational. Play music and let the child tap the steady beat along with it.

title: Flower Arranging — Practice and Variation
description: The child revisits flower arranging with new flowers or greenery, practicing the skills learned on Day 1. This repetition deepens mastery and allows creative expression as the child experiments with different arrangements.
instructions:
1. Set up the tray again: vase, pitcher, flowers or greenery, scissors, towel.
2. 'This time, you will do the whole arrangement yourself. I will watch.'
3. Child pours water, trims stems, and arranges independently.
4. Offer only if needed: 'Would you like to try turning the vase to see all sides?'
5. Child chooses display location.
6. Extension: add a small fern or leaves as greenery between flowers.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the same tray as Day 1. Use different flowers if available for variety. Add some greenery as an extension.

slides.text: 'Remember how we arranged flowers? Today you are going to do the whole thing yourself from start to finish!'
'Start by pouring the water. Then choose your first flower, measure it against the vase, and trim.' Step back and observe.
If the child uses greenery: 'You can add leaves between the flowers to fill in the spaces. This is what real florists do!'

slides.prompt: Create your flower arrangement from start to finish. Pour the water, trim each stem, arrange beautifully. Add greenery if you like. Choose the perfect spot to display it!

slides.text: Clean up the workspace: wipe water, dispose of trimmings, return tools to the tray. 'What a beautiful arrangement! You did it all yourself!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the entire flower arranging process independently from setup to cleanup?

parent_notes: Repetition is essential in Montessori. This second flower arranging session allows the child to work more independently and creatively. You may notice more confidence and efficiency compared to Day 1. Resist the urge to fix or adjust their arrangement — the child's aesthetic choices are valid even if different from yours. Adding greenery is a natural extension that makes arrangements look more professional. Consider making flower arranging a weekly routine — many Montessori classrooms have a flower arranging station that children can use whenever fresh flowers are available. This ongoing practice builds both skill and appreciation for beauty.

title: Reading Phonetic Sentences with 'sh' Words
description: The child reads short sentences that include 'sh' words alongside familiar CVC words. This integrates the new phonogram into connected reading and builds confidence with increasingly complex text.
instructions:
1. Prepare 5-6 short sentences on strips of paper:
   - 'The ship is big.'
   - 'I wish for a fish.'
   - 'She can shut the shed.'
   - 'The shop has a hat.'
   - 'Dash and rush to the ship!'
2. Child reads each sentence, sounding out unfamiliar words.
3. For 'sh' words, remind: 'Remember, s and h together say /sh/.'
4. After reading, child illustrates their favorite sentence.
5. Extension: child creates their own sentence with a 'sh' word.
materials_needed: Prepared sentence strips on paper or card stock

slides.setup_instructions: Write 5-6 short sentences on strips of paper in clear print. Include at least one 'sh' word per sentence. Keep sentences phonetically decodable.

slides.text: 'You can read words, and now you are going to read whole SENTENCES — like in a real book!' Show the first strip: 'The ship is big.'
Child reads, pointing to each word: 'The... ship... is... big.' Celebrate! 'You just read a sentence!' If stuck on 'sh,' remind: 'Those two letters are a team!'
Continue with more sentences. Let the child work at their own pace. Some children will zoom through; others need time to decode each word.
'Which sentence is your favorite? Draw a picture of it!' The child illustrates the sentence, connecting reading to comprehension.

slides.prompt: Read all 5 sentences. Then choose your favorite and draw a picture of it. If you want a challenge, build your OWN sentence with a 'sh' word using the moveable alphabet!

slides.text: 'You are reading sentences now! Real reading — words that tell a story. You should be very proud!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 3 sentences containing 'sh' words with minimal assistance?

parent_notes: Reading sentences is a significant milestone! The child moves from isolated word reading to connected text, which requires tracking from word to word and comprehending meaning. Keep sentences phonetically decodable — avoid irregular words the child has not been taught. The sight words 'the,' 'is,' 'a,' and 'to' may need to be introduced as words to memorize. When the child gets stuck, wait 5 seconds before helping — they are often processing. The illustration activity is not just fun; it demonstrates reading comprehension. If the child draws what the sentence says, they understood it. Creating their own sentences with the moveable alphabet is powerful — now the child is an author!

title: Golden Beads — The 45 Layout
description: The child creates the famous Montessori 45 layout: displaying all quantities from 1 to 9 in each category (units, tens, hundreds, thousands) with their corresponding number cards. This gives a panoramic view of the entire decimal system.
instructions:
1. This requires a very large mat or floor space.
2. Start with units: lay out 1 bead, then 2 beads, then 3... up to 9. Place number cards above each group.
3. Tens: lay out 1 ten bar, 2 ten bars... up to 9 ten bars. Place cards (10, 20, 30... 90).
4. Hundreds: 1 hundred square through 9 hundred squares with cards.
5. Thousands: 1 through 9 thousand cubes with cards.
6. Stand back and admire. 'This is our WHOLE number system! Everything from 1 to 9,000!'
materials_needed: Complete golden bead material (45 units, 45 tens, 45 hundreds, 9 thousands)
Very large floor mat or cleared floor space

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.subheading: The 45 Layout — Our Whole Number System

items: Full golden bead bank (45 of each category)
slides.setup_instructions: Clear a large area. This layout is impressive and needs room! You will use 45 units, 45 tens, 45 hundreds, and 9 thousand cubes.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to lay out our ENTIRE number system. This is something very special!' Start with units: place 1 bead, then 2, then 3... up to 9.
Place unit cards above each group: 1, 2, 3... 9. 'These are all the units we can have before we get a new ten!'
Now tens: 1 ten bar, 2 ten bars... 9 ten bars. Place cards: 10, 20... 90. 'Nine tens — and after that comes a new hundred!'
Hundreds: 1 square through 9 squares with cards. Then thousands: 1 through 9 cubes. Stand back! 'Look at our whole number system!'

slides.prompt: Help build the 45 layout! Count out and place each quantity carefully. When complete, walk along the whole layout and read the numbers aloud: 1, 2, 3... 10, 20, 30... 100, 200... 1000, 2000...

slides.text: 'This is the decimal system — the way humans count everything! From one tiny bead to nine THOUSAND. You just built the whole thing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child help set up the 45 layout and read numbers from each category?

parent_notes: The 45 layout is one of the most dramatic presentations in Montessori math. Named because each category contains 1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9=45 pieces, it gives the child a visual panorama of the entire decimal system. The key insight is that each category goes from 1 to 9, then 'resets' with a new category (10 units become 1 ten, 10 tens become 1 hundred, etc.). This is the concept of exchange that underlies all arithmetic. If you do not have 45 of each category, do a partial layout (units 1-9 and tens 1-9) to demonstrate the pattern. Take a photo of the completed layout — it makes a wonderful portfolio piece!

title: Celebrations Around the World — Holi
description: The child learns about Holi, the Hindu festival of colors celebrated in India and around the world. This lesson explores the traditions, stories, and joy of this spring celebration, building cultural awareness and appreciation for diversity.
instructions:
1. 'Holi is a celebration from India — the Festival of Colors! It celebrates spring and the victory of good over evil.'
2. Show pictures of Holi celebrations: people throwing colored powder, bonfires, sweets.
3. Tell the story of Holika and Prahlad (simplified): good triumphs over evil.
4. 'People throw colored powder at each other — everyone gets covered in rainbow colors!'
5. Activity: create Holi-inspired art using colored powders (chalk dust) on paper.
6. Discuss: 'What does it mean to celebrate spring? What other spring celebrations do you know?'
materials_needed: Colored chalk (crushed into powder) or tempera paint

slides.setup_instructions: Crush colored chalk into powder in small bowls. Protect the workspace with newspaper. Have pictures of Holi ready.

slides.text: 'In India, people celebrate a festival called HOLI — the Festival of Colors! It happens in the spring.' Find India on the globe.
Show pictures: 'Look! People throw colored powder at each other! Everyone is laughing and covered in beautiful colors — pink, yellow, blue, green!'
'Holi celebrates spring coming after winter, and the story of a brave boy named Prahlad who stood up for what was right. Good won over evil!'
'Holi reminds us that color and joy bring people together. Let's make our own Holi art!'

slides.prompt: Create Holi art! Spread glue on paper, then sprinkle colored chalk powder to make a colorful explosion. Use as many colors as you want — the more colorful, the better!

slides.text: 'Holi is a festival of JOY and COLOR. People all around the world have beautiful ways to celebrate!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what Holi is, where it is celebrated, and what it represents?

parent_notes: Cultural celebrations are central to Montessori's peace education. Holi is ideal because it is visually spectacular and celebrates universal themes: the arrival of spring, the triumph of good over evil, and the joy of community. The story of Holika and Prahlad can be simplified for young children: a boy believed in goodness, and even when tested by fire, goodness protected him. The art activity is a sensorial experience of color mixing and texture. If possible, show a short video of actual Holi celebrations — the joy is contagious. This lesson builds empathy and cultural literacy: 'People around the world celebrate in different, beautiful ways.'

title: Read-Aloud: Swimmy by Leo Lionni
description: Reading Leo Lionni's classic about a small black fish who uses cleverness and teamwork to overcome a bigger threat. This story explores themes of individuality, cooperation, and creative problem-solving.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This little fish is named Swimmy. He looks different from the other fish — he is black while they are red.'
2. Read the story, pausing at the beautiful ocean imagery.
3. When Swimmy sees the wonders of the deep sea: 'What beautiful things does Swimmy see?'
4. At the climax: 'How did the little fish solve their problem? They worked TOGETHER!'
5. Discuss: 'Swimmy was different — and that difference helped everyone. How?'
6. Connect: 'Everyone has something special that makes them different. What makes you special?'
materials_needed: Optional: watercolor paints to create ocean art inspired by the illustrations

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably. Leo Lionni's illustrations are created with stamped and watercolor techniques that children love to examine closely.

slides.text: Show the cover: 'This is Swimmy — a little black fish. All his friends are red, but he is different. Let's find out what happens!'
Read through Swimmy's undersea journey. Pause at the beautiful images: 'A lobster like a water-moving machine! A forest of seaweed! An eel with a tail too long to remember!'
At the solution: 'Swimmy had an idea — they could all swim together in the shape of a BIG fish! And Swimmy would be the eye because he was black!'

slides.prompt: After reading: 'How did Swimmy help? His difference — being black — made him the perfect eye! What makes YOU special and different?' Optional: paint an underwater scene inspired by the book.

slides.text: 'Swimmy taught us that being different is not a problem — it is a GIFT. And when we work together, we can do big things!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell how Swimmy solved the problem and explain why his difference was helpful?

parent_notes: Swimmy is a masterpiece of children's literature that addresses individuality, resilience, and cooperation. The story's message — that being different is an asset, not a liability — resonates deeply with Montessori philosophy, which respects each child's unique developmental path. Leo Lionni's illustrations use stamping and watercolor techniques that children can experiment with. The climactic solution (fish swimming in formation) introduces the concept of the whole being greater than the sum of its parts. This book can open rich conversations about times the child has felt different and how being different can be a strength.
